title.narrative: Sustainable Colombia Facility - IDB Trust Fund

description.narrative: Since 2012 the Colombian Government entered a negotiation of a Peace Agreement with the country´s largest guerrilla group -FARC-; after four years of negotiation, a final agreement was achieved on November 2016. This Peace Agreement entails multiple challenges for the rural areas of the country. In order to comply with the final agreement, the Government of Colombia has established a post-conflict strategy called “Colombia in Peace” composed of four Multi Partner Trust Funds: 1) World Bank Trust Fund, 2) United Nations MPTF, 3) EUTF and the 4) Sustainable Colombia Facility – IDB Trust Fund. On 2015 Colombia attended the 21st Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), where the Government of Colombia (GoC), Norway, Germany and the United Kingdom (UK) signed a Joint Declaration of Intent (DoI). The DoI aimed at cutting greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) and promoting sustainable development in Colombia.In order to comply with both the provisions stated in the Peace Agreement, the Joint Declaration, the commitments established in COP21 and the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, the Colombian Government requested the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) to set up the Sustainable Colombia Facility for a 15-year period as one of the long – term post conflict fund for sustainable development by promoting long-term goals that integrate social, economic and environmental development in conflict- affected regions. The objective of this Facility is to support projects and programs aimed at maximizing the environmental, economic and social dividends of peace in Colombia, primarily in territories at the intersection of armed conflict incidence, strategic areas for sustainable rural development and environmental conservation. For this purpose, this facility will address four main challenges: (i) deforestation and loss of natural capital; (ii) rural poverty and territorial development; (iii) low local capacity and lack of coordination; and (iv) climate change challenges.The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) with lead the Facility and manage all contributions from the different donors (as of November, 2017: USD $100M from Norway, USD $ 5M from Switzerland and USD $5M from Sweden), as well as the loan offered to the Colombian Government to act as the Fund’s counterpart.The Inter-American Development Bank’s system and experience in the country has gained strong legitimacy, trust and recognition as a key development actor in Colombia. The Bank also has established internal provisions, routines and policies for eligible expenditures, procurement, technical cooperation and anti-corruption (among others).The governance structure of the Facility will warranty an effective and efficient system for reports, budget allocation, financial management, procurement, monitoring and evaluation of the donor’s Funds. Colombia’s counterpart to this Facility (IDB loan of USD $100M) has not yet been designed on its operation or governance.

Sveriges ambassad har hängivet stöttat Colombias ansträngningar för att uppnå fred i över två årtionden. Som ett resultat av fredsavtalet med FARC, och som svar på de punkter som fastställts genom avtalet, har Colombias regering upprättat en strategi för postkonflikten vid namn Colombia en Paz. Denna strategi består av fyra fonder som etablerats med syfte att dra största möjliga nytta av det internationella utvecklingssamarbetet i landet. Sverige stöder de fyra fonderna. Världsbankens Trust Fond fokuserar på att tillämpa lagen om konfliktens offer (kollektiv gottgörelse) och innefattar ett särskilt avsnitt om tekniskt stöd till ett pilotprojekt inom lantmäteri; FN:s Multi-partner Trust Fund (MPTF) intar ett kortsiktigt perspektiv och åtar strategier för snabba svarsåtgärder; EU:s Trust Fund (EUTF) är en fond med medellångt tidsperspektiv och landsbygdsutveckling som huvudfokus.
Den fjärde fonden, Interamerikanska utvecklingsbankens (IDB) Sustainable Colombia Facility, väntas komplettera de övriga fonderna för postkonflikten genom att främja långsiktiga mål som integrerar social, ekonomisk och miljömässig utveckling i konfliktdrabbade regioner.
Sustainable Colombia Facility söker åtgärda fyra huvudsakliga och sammanlänkade utmaningar: (i) skogsskövling och förlust av naturkapital; (ii) fattigdom på landsbygd och regional utveckling; (iii) bristande institutionell kapacitet och samordning på lokal nivå; och (iv) klimatrelaterade utmaningar. Dessutom väntas initiativet stödja genomförandet av de Globala målen för hållbar utveckling och Colombias nationella bidrag (Intended Nationally Determined Contributions; INDC) till dessa. Fonden prioriterar geografiska områden och provinser som är strategiska för landsbygdsutveckling, miljöskydd och fredsbyggande insatser.

The Sustainable Colombia Facility is part of the Colombia in Peace strategy for post-conflict and is one of the four trust funds created for the implementation of the Peace Agreement with FARC; specifically with regards to the first component of the Agreement: The Comprehensive Rural Reform.
The main outcome of the Facility is to maximize the environmental, economic, and social dividends of peace in Colombia, primarily in territories at the intersection of armed conflict incidence, strategic areas for sustainable rural development and environmental conservation. The Fund is initially established for a period of 15 years and will provide medium-term and long-term support to the post-conflict in Colombia.
The specific objectives of the Facility are: (i) to promote conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity; (ii) to forge and support sustainable rural development; (iii) to support the implementation of national policies that promote climate change mitigation and reduction of deforestation; (iv) to support capacity building in areas affected by the armed conflict; and (v) to mainstream climate change considerations in the development agenda as a cross-sectoral topic.

description.narrative: The sustainable Colombia Facility “Trust Fund” has been established as a mechanism to support the construction and consolidation of peace in Colombia and has contributed to strengthening environmental sustainability and promote rural development initiatives. For this, the Fund has supported the design and implementation of policy and instruments driven to deforestation reduction and restoration in the country. Moreover, the Fund has worked on building local capacities through sustainable productive projects. Both efforts taking place in conflict affected areas as prioritized in the national agenda of the Government of Colombia. After several delays, 2019 was the year in which the above-mentioned results became visible. As of December 2019, the Fund included seven approved technical cooperations/projects in the areas of REDD+, AFOLU, restoration and conservation of transformed ecosystems, sustainable rural development, forest governance and the implementation of the Joint Declaration of Intent (JDI) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Regarding the level of progress, it is important to mention that one of the seven projects began its implementation at the end of 2018, five from January to June 2019 and one in December 2019; therefore, as of December 2019, it is not feasible to measure or report major impacts. However, the following results have been achieved so far per technical cooperation: Support for the REDD+ Project Portfolio in the Choco Biogeographic Region: This TC project aims to reduce the current pressure on forests caused by increased deforestation as well as help mitigate climate change through support to the mechanisms for the reduction of emissions caused by deforestation and the degradation of forests (REDD+) projects based on a voluntary carbon market approach, with Afro-Colombian and indigenous communities located in collective territories of this region. The projects of the Pacific REDD + Project Portfolio are based on the voluntary carbon market, under international standards VCS (Verified Carbon Standard) and CCB (Climate, Community and Biodiversity. The added value of the project is the overall and contextual vision of the three components: (i) forest and territorial governance, (ii) alternative productive development, (iii) monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV). The project has made progress to rise cultural sensitivity, to connect producers with the plants, and to devise monitoring and reporting systems managed directly by the communities. There are three fundamental results of the project: Concerted decisions, Empowerment of community members, Construction of networks and community and Deforestation, which has been stopped in approximately 11,500 hectares, avoiding the emission of 6,065,860 toms of CO2 equivalent. Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification of the Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Uses Sector (AFOLU) in Colombia: This project aims to help consolidate the National System of Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification for the supervision of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and reductions. During the first half of 2019, annual deforestation figures in Colombia for 2018 were finalized and published. The inputs of the project enable Colombia to identify causes and agents of deforestation included in the country’s annual deforestation report. There have been difficulties in accessing information through external sources, making progress and the generation of new calculations more complicated; however, to speed up the implementation of activities related with gathering information in the field and its validation, it is crucial the participation and support of the research institutes Restoration and Conservation of the Transformed Ecosystems in La Macarena National Park: The project specifically proposes to improve the connectivity of ecosystems transformed in two ways: physical connectivity, through ecological corridors; and functionality, which implies spontaneous dynamics within ecosystems as indicators of ecosystem health. Progress is being made in the biophysical and socioeconomic characterization of the territory where the farms and beneficiary families are located. To date, the project has strengthened the relationship between local peasant communities and environmental entities; the challenge is to replicate the dialogue to other sectors. The project has also helped farmers learn about new successful experiences with non-timber products Promotion of Innovative Strategies for Sustainable Rural Development and Environmental Conservation: This project aims to promote resilient and low-carbon rural development in seven municipalities affected by conflict by supporting the implementation of six associative sustainable productive projects (agricultural, livestock, forestry, fisheries, and aquaculture) and green businesses, with six associations of small rural producers. For now, the project has identified and approved different action lines. In terms of impact, the financing of the six productive eligible projects is expected to improve the annual average net income of beneficiaries through increased productivity and the implementation of low- carbon sustainable productive practices or through climate change adaptation principles. Strengthening of Forest Governance: This project seeks to contribute to the implementation of the comprehensive strategy for deforestation control (EICD) and the sustainable management of forests with a territorial approach trough i) capacity building among the actors associated with the deforestation control protocol , ii) promotion of associations enabling the development of community forestry activities and iii) contribution to the construction of the forest traceability system of products from natural forests contribute to the dynamics of legal forest markets. Phase I of the project, focused to guarantee institutional coordination and the identification of beneficiaries was carried out during 2019. Phase 2, which corresponds to the formulation and implementation of the forest management plans and has the greatest weight in terms of investment, will be executed in January of 2020. Strengthening of Local Capacities for Project Management and Territorial Innovation Models: This project aims to generate technical capacities in municipalities affected by conflict for the structuring of projects of great economic, social, and environmental impact – at both local and regional levels – in associative productive areas (agricultural, livestock, forestry, fisheries, and aquaculture), environmental sustainability, and green business. In 2019 the activities focused on the structuring of projects, the contracting of consulting services to generate technical capabilities in PDET municipalities is planned for the first half of 2020. Coordination and Implementation of the Joint Declaration of Intent – JDI: This project aims to support the government of Colombia in the coordination and implementation of the Joint Declaration of Intention (JDI) for REDD+ in 3.4 million hectares within 30 years. In accordance with the fifth report by the MADS on the fulfillment of milestones under modality 1 (actions to collaborate on the design and implementation of policies and structures that enable the reduction of emissions from deforestation and promote a low-carbon economy), 48 of the 63 JDI milestones have been met. One challenge for this project is the adequate management of indigenous territories that are a potential part of the livestock landscapes, given appropriate and timely regulations. Activities to work on in 2020 include a workplan defined in collaboration with FEDEGAN on the sustainable livestock approach to optimize resources by leveraging FEDEGAN’s vaccination staff located in the targeted territories. This sustainable livestock approach involves clean production, associative strengthening, and a methodological structure for producers to use new technologies.
